{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3731025,"name":"Sumter Link","username":"Link2815","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/link2815/{size}/157100_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-04T16:47:44.672Z","cooked":"

Restocking/replacing some tools during the offseason. Curious if anyone has a wire strippers that they really like. The multi gauge ones that we currently use can be finicky with the 22awg CAN wire. If there is a multi gauge brand that’s good would love to stay there, would also be interested in one that is only 22awg. Thanks in advance.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2025-09-05T21:55:54.988Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":25,"reads":370,"readers_count":369,"score":249.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":505953,"topic_slug":"wire-stripper-recommendations","display_username":"Sumter Link","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":34765,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/wire-stripper-recommendations/505953/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3731032,"name":"Jared Van Horn","username":"CuteRedpandas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cuteredpandas/{size}/243322_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-04T16:59:27.709Z","cooked":"
amazon.com

Amazon.com: IRWIN VISE-GRIP Wire Stripper, 2 inch Jaw, Cuts 10-24 AWG, ProTouch...

The IRWIN VISE-GRIP Self-Adjusting Wire Stripper, 8", makes stripping wire from 10-24 AWG easier than ever. It has a self-adjusting mechanism and a swivel knob for micro-adjustments for gauges smaller than 20 AWG. The wire crimper crimps 22 AWG...

$24.99

I’m a fan of these guys

Link2815:

Curious if anyone has a wire strippers that they really like.

We have, and use, several different styles because some work better with certain kinds of wire than others, and students often have preferences as to which they find easier to use.

For small gauge wire including CAN, these seem to work pretty well and have been what I see most students choosing. They’re inexpensive (mostly plastic) knockoffs of the Knipex design, but we have a couple that have seen quite a bit of use and haven’t failed yet. They have a stop which helps with consistent strip lengths too. Always figured if we liked them we’d eventually upgrade to a sturdier version, but so far there’s been no need - though we do generally use one of our heavier-duty strippers for most power wiring.

Do these go down to 3mm? The official knipex ones only go down to 4mm, which is too long for molex sl.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2025-09-04T17:26:16.573Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":280,"readers_count":279,"score":61.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":505953,"topic_slug":"wire-stripper-recommendations","display_username":"Tim Winters","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":48574,"username":"bbonner","name":"Brett B Bonner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bbonner/{size}/155176_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19820,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"78 AIR Strike Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/wire-stripper-recommendations/505953/6","custom_user_title":"78 AIR Strike Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3731056,"name":"Chris Bale","username":"cbale2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-04T17:26:55.818Z","cooked":"

We’ve always been pretty happy with these strippers from Home Depot.

Screenshot 2025-09-04 at 13-17-55 Klein Tools Katapult Wire Stripper and Cutter for 8-20 AWG Solid and 10-22 AWG Stranded Wire 11063W - The Home Depot650×650 167 KB

We use them for CAN wire was well, though we have found that not all CAN wire is created equally and depending on where you get it (we get ours from CTRE or ThriftyBot), wire with a thinner coating may be hard to use with these. If that happens, we just use a pair of small-gauge manual strippers like these:

Screenshot 2025-09-04 at 13-22-16 Klein Tools Wire Stripper_Cutter 16-26 AWG Stranded 11046 - The Home Depot650×470 185 KB

We use these for all of our wire.
https://www.automationdirect.com/adc/shopping/catalog/tools_-a-_test_equipment/pliers_-a-_cutting_tools/wire_-a-_cable_stripping_tools/dn-ws
Good use of the automation direct voucher if you don’t have a use for it.

These also look pretty good, but I don’t have experience with them. https://www.automationdirect.com/adc/shopping/catalog/tools_-a-_test_equipment/pliers_-a-_cutting_tools/wire_-a-_cable_stripping_tools/jt20050

Since you have a pair of the knipex strippers, have you looked at adjusting the slider on the Knipex strippers?

Screenshot 2025-09-04 at 13.46.001256×846 629 KB

Adjusting the slider adjusts how deep the blades cut into the insulation. Often times it needs to be adjusted, especially if switching between thick and thin insulation.

Another project farm watcher, finally. I recommend this guy to everyone asking about different tools

","post_number":16,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2025-09-04T18:45:37.201Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":14,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":215,"readers_count":214,"score":58.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":505953,"topic_slug":"wire-stripper-recommendations","display_username":"Sumter Link","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":24506,"username":"s3529","name":"Robertson Robotics","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/s3529/{size}/121055_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":34765,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/wire-stripper-recommendations/505953/16","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3731182,"name":"Ryan Reed","username":"Ryan_Reed","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ryan_reed/{size}/268514_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-04T19:41:38.960Z","cooked":"

Looks like the wire is slipping through that plastic part in the front. That is supposed to hold the wire (and insulation) in place, with the upper blade pulling the insulation back. Hard to pin down the cause though.

When you close the jaws, are the blades touching each other? They should be aligned so that it makes a clean cut.

Maybe at max tension, the blade is going too deep and the blade is stuck in the copper?

Could also be that the blades are dull, but sounds like you are saying it never worked well.

Maybe the plastic bit in the front just isn’t gripping that wire well enough?

IMG_77071206×1399 108 KB

these.

These are the best.

In all seriousness though, I have these and they are extremely sharp and do a wonderful job cutting through everything (4gauge like butter) and strip every size wonderfully. They have a crimp for those older style inline crimps. Pliers on the end and everything, they are like 3/8-1/2 in thick by the cutters and stripper sections. They don’t have a stripper for anything bigger than 10 gauge (I just end up using the cutters for that kind of stuff though)
